Data from a regional climate model and some 150 wind speed stations throughout Germany contributed to the gridding of the wind dataset. The climate model simulation has captured general features of the wind field throughout Germany. The station data were used to correct biases inherent to the climate model simulation.

The general pattern of the 90th percentile of hourly wind speed is similar in winter (DJF; Fig. Fig. 11a) and summer (JJA; Fig. Fig. 11b) over the period 1995–2012. Nonetheless, the 90th percentile values are clearly higher in DJF (5–22 m/s) compared to JJA (3–15 m/s), particularly in the Erzgebirge and western Germany. The 90th percentile maps also depict several interesting features, including the north to south decrease in wind speed over the lowland plains and in mountain valleys, and the higher wind speed along the coast and on mountain ridges and peaks.

4.3.3 Annual sum of global radiation

Observations from 32 German ground stations were used to correct satellite-derived global radiation data. The most significant adjustments were applied during the winter months and particularly relate to the snow-cloud misinterpretation inherent in satellite data.

Figure Fig. 12 presents the two most extreme years in terms of the annual total of global radiation in the period 1995–2012, namely 1995 (Fig. Fig. 12a) and 2003 (Fig. Fig. 12b). In 1995, the annual global radiation total was exceptionally low over southern Germany due to frequent west winds and increased cloud cover. In the upper Rhine Valley, the flatlands of Bavaria and eastern Germany, values of between 1120 and 1160 kWh/m2 were reached, and in northern and western Germany 1000 and 1100 kWh/m2. In the elevated areas, annual global radiation totals were generally below 1000 kWh/m2. In 2003, the annual global radiation totals were above the climatological mean nationwide. Overall, it was a very warm, dry and exceptionally sunny year throughout Central Europe. The Sauerland, Harz and coastal regions received lower radiation total (1040–1200 kWh/m2) but with values still above the climatological mean. In regions south of the low German mountain ranges, the values exceeded 1300 kWh/m2.

4.3.4 Perceived temperature

The RayMan bio-climate model (Matzarakis et al. 2010) was run in the Rhine-Main area with the gridded climate variables air temperature, relative humidity, global radiation and cloud cover, to obtain perceived temperature (Staiger et al. 2012) on 14.07.1995 at 5 UTC (Fig. Fig. 13a) and 12 UTC (Fig. Fig. 13b). Albedo and surface emissivity values were prescribed on the basis of the CLC land use data (following Pineda et al. 2002). The simulations were run in order to show the usefulness of the described dataset for applications in the framework of planning and health issues (Rosenfelder et al. 2015).

At 5 UTC, weather conditions were warm and humid in the Rhine-Main area. Early in the morning, air temperature was still high in urban areas (>20°C) compared to the rural surroundings (16–20°C) which can be attributed to the UHI effect. Elevated areas were also comparably warm due to a temperature inversion. Relative humidity was above 80% everywhere, and in the Frankfurt area, it was as high as 90%. Wind speed in most areas was lower than 1.5 m/s, except for the area around Donnersberg and on the ridges of the low mountain ranges. It is evident that in comparison with the surrounding countryside, perceived temperature was considerably higher in urban areas with values of 20 to 24°C.

At 12 UTC, hot air temperatures of more than 30°C and low relative humidity (<50%) prevailed in the Rhine/Main area with not much difference between the cities and the countryside. In the mountains, air temperature was considerably cooler, with an approximate lapse rate of ∼1°C/100 m and relative humidity was higher (∼70%). Wind speed was variable with values between 1 and 4.5 m/s, although lower in elevated areas. Global radiation was higher than 800 W/m2 in most areas, but due to local cloud, some confined areas received less than 600 W/m2 within 11–12 UTC. Some convective showers approached the region from the north and led to a decrease in air temperature (<20°C) and an increase in relative humidity (>80%). Perceived temperature was highest in the lowlands of the Rhine/Main area with hot spots of ∼40°C around Frankfurt and Gernsheim (areas of high air temperature and low wind speed). In the mountains and over the north-eastern part of the Rhine-Main area, perceived temperature was considerably lower (15–25°C).
